results.title: Nobody Makes Films Like Alex Garland. But He Might Stop Making Them.
results.abstract: The man behind “Men” says of directing, “I don’t particularly enjoy it. It’s something I have to force myself to do.”

multimedia.caption: Alex Garland wrote and directed “Men,” and said his friends’ interpretation of the film “is 180 degrees different from what I thought it was.”

results.title: How Hollywood and the Media Fueled the Political Rise of J.D. Vance
results.abstract: “Hillbilly Elegy,” a best-selling memoir that became a star-studded film, raised the profile of the onetime “Never Trump guy” who won an Ohio primary with the help of the former president.
des_facet: Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis (Book)

results.abstract: The defamation trial involving the actors is entering a new stage as Ms. Heard faces aggressive cross-examination from Mr. Depp’s lawyers.

results.title: In ‘The Innocents,’ Kids Behaving Deadly
results.abstract: Eskil Vogt, the Oscar-nominated co-writer of “The Worst Person in the World,” explores a childhood paradox in his new horror movie: how kids can be both innocent and cruel.

results.title: The Spell ‘Doctor Strange’ Is Missing: Sam Raimi’s Macabre Vision
results.abstract: The auteur put his mark on the new film in a few spots, but his “Spider-Man” movies prove that superhero tales needn’t be so visually bland.
des_facet: Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness (Movie)

results.title: When Motherhood Is a Horror Show
results.abstract: For the onscreen moms in “The Baby,” “Umma” and “Lamb” — and for an ascendant class of sardonic mom influencers — the source of psychological torture is motherhood itself.

results.title: Meet this year’s Cannes jury.
results.abstract: Each year, the jury chooses the festival’s top prizes, including the Palme d’Or. This year it’s led by the actor Vincent Lindon.

results.title: The festival gives Forest Whitaker an honorary Palme d’Or lifetime achievement award.
results.abstract: The festival’s opening ceremony played clips from some of his of movies, including “Bird,” “Ghost Dog,” “The Color of Money” and “Panic Room.”

results.title: Fred Ward, Star of ‘The Right Stuff’ and ‘Henry and June,’ Dies at 79
results.abstract: A versatile actor, he was best known throughout his long career for playing tough, resilient characters. But he also had a subtle side.

results.title: Joanna Barnes, Actress in ‘The Parent Trap’ and Its Remake, Dies at 87
results.abstract: In 1961, she played a vixenish fortune hunter. In 1998, she played the character’s mother. In between, she kept busy on TV and also wrote novels.

multimedia.caption: The actress and author Joanna Barnes in an undated photo. “When I’m beginning to feel confined at writing,” she once said, “I take time out for acting.”

results.title: Gloria Parker, Maestra of the Musical Glasses, Dies at 100
results.abstract: She played many instruments and appeared on radio and television, but she was best known for the skill that led to a role in Woody Allen’s “Broadway Danny Rose.”

multimedia.caption: Gloria Parker playing the musical glasses at her home in 1984, the year she appeared in Woody Allen’s movie “Broadway Danny Rose.” “I am just an emissary,” she said, “God’s worker to bring glasses to the world.”
